awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Passive, Low-Energy Technology for Extracting High-Value Products from Algae
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer Phase I project is to commercialize technology to extract high-value components (e.g., omegea3 fatty acids) from algae. Omega3 fatty acids are an essential part of the human diet and are sourced primarily from fish oil; the fish actually get Omega3 from eating algae. Algae present a direct source.  However, the high cost of extracting the Omega3 fatty acids from the algae, which represents about 50% of the production cost, is a significant cost hurdle that needs to be overcome. This project seeks to develop and commercialize a novel algae oil extraction technology to reduce the production cost of high-value products such as Omega 3 fatty acids from algae. 

The technical objectives in this Phase I research project are to build an algal oil extraction system and demonstrate low-energy extraction configurations suitable for extracting high-value components from algae for nutraceuticals. The project will employ its proprietary computer models, based on Carnegie Mellon University research to develop a system to economically extract the oil from algae. This work will be accomplished through the following research objectives. First, specific strain(s) of algae will have their material response evaluated to assess their release thresholds. Secondly, models will inform and/or guide the extraction technology development so that the extraction process is optimized for a particular algae strain. Third, a low-energy extraction system will be built and tested with the goal of providing a system that can lead to a low cost economical way of extracting high value products such as Omega3 fatty acids from algae.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The global population has seen an increase in demand for preventative health care, with the knowledge that proactive health ultimately leads to better quality of life and lowers expenses. Consequently, the nutraceutical, pharmaceutical, and cosmetic industries are working to provide products that are not only effective, but also natural, organic, and environmentally conscious. Many species of algae naturally produce a wealth of highly beneficial byproducts to meet this need and have become powerful directions for these markets. There are several benefits to using algae as a feedstock crop for nutraceutical production. Algae can yield significantly more biomass per acre than traditional crops and competes little with food crop, freshwater, and land. In addition, algae can be grown on otherwise unproductive land using non-potable water. Therefore, algae nutraceuticals have great potential.

For this NSF STTR, Innovalgae focused on developing a low energy approach for extracting products from algae. The industry currently employs extraction methods that are either too costly or chemically unstable for consumption due to the use of noxious solvents. Utilization of algae for nutraceutical production is currently limited by several technical hurdles, such as scaling mass production systems, developing more productive strains of algae, and the high costs of harvesting the algae and extracting nutraceutical products. Therefore, there exists an important need for low-cost, chemical-free techniques for "lysing" or breaking open cells that can be adapted for consumable products (e.g. Omega 3's) without compromising yield or quality. InnovAlgae's unique value proposition is that we can lyse & extract these products in a way that is cheaper, safer, more effective, and more environmentally conscious than the methods currently practiced.

InnovAlgae developed a method for extracting and recovering products from algae while still in water. This was conducted in three objectives: (1) two algae species were evaluated for material response and release thresholds, (2) proprietary software models guided the technology development and optimization for each particular algae strain, (3) a low-energy extraction system was built and tested for an economical way of extracting Omega 3s without the use of chemical solvents. InnovAlgae has also developed a number of mutually beneficial partnerships with algae growers and nutraceutical manufacturers. This project helped generate technology for the algae industry that will be able to be cheaper and more environmentally conscious than other methods.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/09/2017
Modified by: Patrick S Dougherty
